LeCun argues that companies like Anthropic and OpenAI are being inconsistent by warning about existential AI risks while simultaneously developing more powerful AI systems, and he believes that fears about large language models are overblown. 			<div class="entry-content__content-side"></div>
						<p><strong>Yann LeCun, Meta's chief AI scientist, has taken a direct shot at Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei on Threads, making clear just how sharply the AI community is split over the future of general artificial intelligence.</strong></p><div class="mobile-view"><div class="ad-notice">Ad</div>
    <div class="ad-row">
        <div class="ad-container ad-m ad-feed" style="min-height: 600px;">
            <div id="DEC_M_Incontent-1" class="ad-m ad-feed"></div>
        </div>
            </div>
    </div>
<p>When a Threads user asked if Amodei was an "AI Doomer," an "AI Hyper," or both, LeCun didn't hold back: "He is a doomer, but he keeps working on 'AGI'." LeCun argued there are only two possible explanations for this: "He is intellectually dishonest and/or morally corrupt."</p>
<p>Alternatively, LeCun suggested, Amodei could be suffering from a "huge superiority complex," believing "only he is enlightened enough to have access to AI, but the unwashed masses are too stupid or immoral to use such a powerful tool" In LeCun's view, Amodei is "deluded about the dangers and power of current AI systems."</p>
<div class="content-img-side flex items-center gap-3"><figure id="attachment_24385" aria-describedby="caption-attachment-24385" style="width: 620px" class="wp-caption alignnone"><a href="https://the-decoder.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/lecun_vs_amodei_threads.png"><img data-lazyloaded="1" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHdpZHRoPSI2MjAiIGhlaWdodD0iNzY3IiB2aWV3Qm94PSIwIDAgNjIwIDc2NyI+PHJlY3Qgd2lkdGg9IjEwMCUiIGhlaWdodD0iMTAwJSIgc3R5bGU9ImZpbGw6I2YyZjJmMjtmaWxsLW9wYWNpdHk6IDAuMTsiLz48L3N2Zz4=" fetchpriority="high" decoding="async" class="wp-image-24385 size-full" data-src="https://the-decoder.com/wp-content/uploads/2025/06/lecun_vs_amodei_threads.png" alt="Threads screenshot: Yann LeCun calls Anthropics CEO Dario Amodei a morally corrupt doomer working on AGI." width="620" height="767"></a><figcaption id="caption-attachment-24385" class="wp-caption-text">LeCun publicly criticizes Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei on Threads, accusing him of moral dishonesty for pursuing AGI while warning of AI risks. | Image: <a target="_blank" rel="noopener" href="https://www.threads.com/@yannlecun/post/DKmejx6tFXd?xmt=AQF0ptpMYQkwdpX4dNPfZwCmGt2zqt12hnD9LN3wrXzH-g">Screenshot via Threads</a></figcaption></figure>

<h2>Fundamental disagreements over AI's future</h2>
<p>LeCun's remarks highlight a much deeper debate about the direction of AI research. Companies like Anthropic and OpenAI are racing to commercialize ever more powerful large language models (LLMs), often warning that these systems could pose existential risks to humanity. LeCun sees this narrative—and the focus on LLMs themselves—as misguided if the goal is to achieve genuine, human-level intelligence.</p><div class="mobile-view"><div class="ad-notice">Ad</div>

<p>He points out that LLMs like GPT-X or Claude have significant limitations. According to LeCun, these models struggle with basic logic, lack real-world understanding, and cannot retain information long-term. He argues they are incapable of rational thinking or <a href="https://the-decoder.com/even-openais-o1-preview-fails-at-travel-planning/">complex planning</a>, and ultimately can't be relied on since they only produce convincing answers when their training data covers the topic.</p>
<p>"If you are a student interested in building the next generation of AI systems, don't work on LLMs," <a href="https://the-decoder.com/metas-lecun-says-students-interested-in-next-gen-ai-shouldnt-bother-with-llms/">LeCun said a year ago</a>. He believes the field is already dominated by major companies, and that LLMs aren't the path to real intelligence.</p>
<p>Instead, LeCun and his team at Meta are focused on "world models"; AI systems designed to build a genuine understanding of their environment. In a recent study, <a href="https://the-decoder.com/well-it-looks-like-metas-yann-lecun-may-have-been-right-about-ai-again/">Meta researchers introduced V-JEPA, an AI model that learns intuitive physical reasoning from videos through self-supervised training</a>. Compared to multimodal LLMs like Gemini or Qwen, V-JEPA demonstrated a much stronger grasp of physics, despite needing far less training data.</p><div class="mobile-view"><div class="ad-notice">Ad</div>

                    <span>Summary</span>
                </div>
                <div class="summary__text"><ul>
 	<li>Meta's Yann LeCun has accused Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei of intellectual dishonesty and moral corruption, criticizing him for pursuing general artificial intelligence despite warnings about its risks.</li>
 	<li>LeCun argues that companies like Anthropic and OpenAI are being inconsistent by warning about existential AI risks while simultaneously developing more powerful AI systems, and he believes that fears about large language models are overblown.</li>
 	<li>He advocates for the use of world models such as V-JEPA, which use self-supervised learning to understand physical relationships more effectively and with less training data than multimodal language models.</li>
</ul></div>

text:
Matthias is the co-founder and publisher of THE DECODER, exploring how AI is fundamentally changing the relationship between humans and computers.

Content Summary

Yann LeCun, Meta's chief AI scientist, has taken a direct shot at Anthropic CEO Dario Amodei on Threads, making clear just how sharply the AI community is split over the future of general artificial intelligence.

Ad

When a Threads user asked if Amodei was an "AI Doomer," an "AI Hyper," or both, LeCun didn't hold back: "He is a doomer, but he keeps working on 'AGI'." LeCun argued there are only two possible explanations for this: "He is intellectually dishonest and/or morally corrupt."

Alternatively, LeCun suggested, Amodei could be suffering from a "huge superiority complex," believing "only he is enlightened enough to have access to AI, but the unwashed masses are too stupid or immoral to use such a powerful tool" In LeCun's view, Amodei is "deluded about the dangers and power of current AI systems."

Share Recommend our article Share

Fundamental disagreements over AI's future

LeCun's remarks highlight a much deeper debate about the direction of AI research. Companies like Anthropic and OpenAI are racing to commercialize ever more powerful large language models (LLMs), often warning that these systems could pose existential risks to humanity. LeCun sees this narrative—and the focus on LLMs themselves—as misguided if the goal is to achieve genuine, human-level intelligence.

Ad

Ad THE DECODER Newsletter The most important AI news straight to your inbox. ✓ Weekly ✓ Free ✓ Cancel at any time Please leave this field empty

He points out that LLMs like GPT-X or Claude have significant limitations. According to LeCun, these models struggle with basic logic, lack real-world understanding, and cannot retain information long-term. He argues they are incapable of rational thinking or complex planning, and ultimately can't be relied on since they only produce convincing answers when their training data covers the topic.

"If you are a student interested in building the next generation of AI systems, don't work on LLMs," LeCun said a year ago. He believes the field is already dominated by major companies, and that LLMs aren't the path to real intelligence.

Instead, LeCun and his team at Meta are focused on "world models"; AI systems designed to build a genuine understanding of their environment. In a recent study, Meta researchers introduced V-JEPA, an AI model that learns intuitive physical reasoning from videos through self-supervised training. Compared to multimodal LLMs like Gemini or Qwen, V-JEPA demonstrated a much stronger grasp of physics, despite needing far less training data.

Ad
rewritten:
In a fiery exchange on Threads, Meta's AI guru Yann LeCun didn't mince words about Anthropic's chief Dario Amodei. This spat underscores the rift in the AI realm regarding its future path. When someone questioned whether Amodei fits into categories like "AI Doomer" or "Hyper," LeCun shot back labeling him as pessimistic yet still chasing after general artificial intelligence (AGI). According to LeCun, there are only two reasons for this contradiction: either intellectual dishonesty and moral bankruptcy or perhaps a case of thinking he's uniquely suited to wield AI while doubting others' abilities to handle it responsibly.

LeCun stands firm against companies such as Anthropic and OpenAI, suggesting they're talking out both sides of their mouth by warning about massive threats from powerful language models they’re also keenly developing. He believes these fears are exaggerated since models like GPT-X fall short when faced with logical reasoning and can't grasp real-world dynamics without ample data input.

Instead of betting on large language frameworks already monopolized by industry giants, LeCun advocates shifting focus towards systems known as world models that learn more organically how things interconnect physically—an approach exemplified by Meta’s new V-JEPA project. It shines brighter than other advanced AIs thanks to understanding physics well with less info needed upfront compared to popular multimodal platforms; all done through smart self-training processes rather than sifting heaps of prior information records alone.
